abstract.para: The topic provides a list of tools that you can use to configure &selnx;.

section.title: The chcon command
section.para: The command name chcon stands for change context. The command can change the full security context of a file to the value provided on the CLI, or it can change parts of the context. Alternatively, you can provide a file that serves as a reference. The change is not reflected in the policy, so a relabel of the file will reset the context back to its definition in the policy.

section.title: getenforce and setenforce commands
section.para: The setenforce command temporarily changes the SELinux mode to enforcing or permissive. You cannot use this command to disable &selnx;. Remember that the change persists only until the next reboot. To change the state permanently, follow the description in .
where MODE_ID is 0 for the permissive mode or 1 for the enforcing mode.

section.title: The semanage command
section.para: The semanage command can be used to configure parts of the policy without the need to recompile the policy from sources. The command enables you to perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: manage Booleans by using the boolean argument. For details about Booleans, refer to .
adjust the context of files by using the fcontext argument. For details about file contexts, refer to .
manage user mappings using the login argument
manage &selnx; users using the user argument
manage &selnx; policy modules using the module argument

section.para: Other options are specific to particular semanage commands and are described in corresponding sections.

section.title: The semanage fcontext command
section.para: Using the semanage fcontext command, you can perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: query file context definitions
add contexts on files
add your own rules

section.para: Changes performed to the file context using the semanage fcontext command do not require modifications or recompilation of the policy.
On top of the common options described in , the semanage fcontext command takes the following options:

listitem.para: The option enables you to use the context of the provided path context to label files in a different directory (the provided target path). For example, you want to assign the same context as /home has to an alternative home directory /export/home. If you use this option, you need to provide the source path and the target path:
To specify a file type. Use one of the following values:
a - all files, which is also the default value
b - a block device
c - a character device
d - a directory
f - regular files
l - a symbolic link
p - a named pipe
s - a socket
